title: The Nature and Experience of Entrepreneurial Passion
keywords: entrepreneurial passion, role identity, emotions, cognition, behavior
abstract: Entrepreneurial passion plays a crucial role in entrepreneurship but lacks theoretical understanding. This paper builds on fragmented extant work to conceptualize the nature of entrepreneurial passion associated with salient entrepreneurial role identities and theorizes the mechanisms that provide coherence to goal-directed cognitions and behaviors during the pursuit of entrepreneurial effectiveness.
original_filename: 17 - Cardon et al. 2009.pdf

title: How Do Feelings Influence Effort? an Empirical Study of Entrepreneurs' Affect and Venture Effort
keywords: entrepreneurial affect, affect, venture effort, temporal focus, affect-as-information
abstract: This study investigates how feelings influence the effort of entrepreneurs. Using experience sampling methodology, data were collected from 46 entrepreneurs over 24 days. The findings support the affect-as-information theory, showing that negative affect directly predicts immediate task-related effort, while positive affect predicts future-oriented effort beyond what is immediately required, mediated by future temporal focus.
original_filename: 18 - Foo et al. 2009.pdf

title: Competing Models of Entrepreneurial Intentions
keywords: entrepreneurship, intentions, models, prediction, behavior
abstract: Entrepreneurship is an intentional process that involves identifying opportunities over threats. Intention models are well-suited to predict planned behavior like entrepreneurship because new businesses require significant planning. The study compares Ajzen’s theory of planned behavior (TPB) and Shapero’s model of the entrepreneurial event (SEE), finding strong statistical support for both, emphasizing the importance of intentions as the best predictor of entrepreneurial activities.
original_filename: 19 - Krueger et al. 2000.pdf

title: Survival of the Fittest? Entrepreneurial Human Capital and the Persistence of Underperforming Firms
keywords: survival, performance, threshold, entrepreneurship, human capital
abstract: This paper challenges the unidimensional relationship between economic performance and organizational survival by proposing a threshold model. The authors argue that firms with lower thresholds may continue to operate despite poor performance, influenced by factors such as entrepreneurial human capital characteristics like alternative employment opportunities and psychic income from entrepreneurship. Using data from 1,547 new U.S. businesses, the study supports this model.
original_filename: 20 - Gimeno et al. 1997.pdf

title: Venturing for Others with Heart and Head: How Compassion Encourages Social Entrepreneurship
keywords: compassion, social entrepreneurship, integrative thinking, prosocial motivation, commitment
abstract: Social entrepreneurship has emerged as a promising organizational form that uses market-based methods to address social issues. The motivations behind this phenomenon remain undertheorized, but research suggests that compassion can supplement traditional self-oriented motivations. This paper builds a model of three mechanisms—integrative thinking, prosocial cost-benefit analysis, and commitment to alleviating others' suffering—that transform compassion into social entrepreneurship. It also identifies the institutional conditions under which these mechanisms are most likely to occur.
original_filename: 21 - Miller et al. 2012.pdf

title: Entrepreneurial Exits and Innovation
keywords: entrepreneurial exits, innovation, information confidentiality, venture capital, biotechnology
abstract: We examine how initial public offerings (IPOs) and acquisitions affect entrepreneurial innovation as measured by patent counts and forward patent citations. Using a firm-year panel dataset of venture capital-backed biotechnology firms founded between 1980 and 2000, we find that innovation quality is highest under private ownership and lowest under public ownership, with acquisition intermediate between the two. These results suggest that information confidentiality mechanisms shape innovation outcomes.
original_filename: Aggarwal, V. A., & Hsu, D. H. (2014). Entrepreneurial exit and innovation.pdf

title: Exploitation, Exploration, and Process Management: the Productivity Dilemma Revisited
keywords: exploitation, exploration, process management, dynamic capabilities, organizational adaptation
abstract: Twenty-five years after Abernathy's observations, the pressures for organizations to meet multiple, often inconsistent, contextual demands have escalated. We develop a contingency view of process management's influence on both technological innovation and organizational adaptation, arguing that while process management activities are beneficial in stable contexts, they are fundamentally inconsistent with all but incremental innovation and change. Ambidextrous organizational forms provide the complex contexts for these inconsistent activities to coexist.
original_filename: Benner, M. J., & Tushman, M. L. (2003). Exploitation, exploration, and process management- The productivity dilemma revisited. Academy of Management Review.pdf

title: Does Going Public Affect Innovation?
keywords: going public, innovation, ipo, patents, firm strategy
abstract: This paper investigates the effects of going public on innovation by comparing the innovation activity of firms that go public with those that withdraw their IPO filing and remain private. Using patent-based metrics, it finds that the quality of internal innovation declines following the IPO, leading to an exodus of skilled inventors and a decline in the productivity of remaining inventors. However, public firms attract new human capital and acquire external innovation.
original_filename: Bernstein, S. (2015). Does going public affect innovation.pdf

title: Why the Lean Start-Up Changes Everything
keywords: lean start-up, entrepreneurship, business model, experimentation, customer feedback
abstract: Launching a new enterprise has traditionally been a hit-or-miss proposition with high failure rates. However, a methodology called the "lean start-up" is emerging as a countervailing force that can make the process less risky by favoring experimentation over elaborate planning and customer feedback over intuition. This article provides an overview of lean start-up techniques and their evolution, explaining how they could ignite a new entrepreneurial economy.
original_filename: Blank 2013 Why the lean startup changes everything.pdf

title: The Art of Continuous Change: Linking Complexity Theory and Time-Paced Evolution in Relentlessly Shifting Organizations
keywords: complexity theory, continuous change, innovation, organizations, time-paced evolution
abstract: This inductive study examines how organizations engage in continuous change through multiple-product innovation. Successful firms blend limited structure with extensive communication to create improvisation within current projects, rely on a wide variety of low-cost probes into the future, and link present and future through rhythmic, time-paced transition processes. The research challenges the punctuated equilibrium model by focusing on the endemic nature of continuous change in high-velocity industries.
original_filename: Brown, S. L., & Eisenhardt, K. M. (1997). The art of continuous change- Linking complexity theory and time-paced evolution in relentlessly shifting organizations.pdf

title: Can You Gig It? an Empirical Examination of the Gig Economy and Entrepreneurial Activity
keywords: gigeconomy, digitalplatforms, crowdfunding, entrepreneurship, differenceindifference
abstract: We examine how the entry of gig-economy platforms influences local entrepreneurial activity. On one hand, such platforms may reduce entrepreneurial activity by offering stable employment for the unemployed and underemployed. On the other hand, they may enable entrepreneurial activity by providing work flexibility that allows the entrepreneur to redeploy resources strategically in pursuit of an ascending venture. To resolve this tension, we examine the entry of the ridesharing platform UberX into local areas using two measures of entrepreneurial activity: crowdfunding campaign launches at Kickstarter and levels of self-employment from the Current Population Survey.
original_filename: Burtch, G., Carnahan, S., & Greenwood, B. N. (2018). Can you gig it- An empirical examination of the gig economy and entrepreneurial activity.pdf

title: Who Leaves, Where To, and Why Worry? Employee Mobility, Entrepreneurship, and Effects on Source Firm Performance
keywords: entrepreneurship, strategic human capital, employee mobility, complementary assets, professional service firms
abstract: The paper theorizes that the value provided by a firm’s complementary assets significantly influences employee exit decisions and their subsequent impact on the firm's performance. Using data from legal services firms in the U.S., it was found that higher-earning employees are less likely to leave but more likely to start new ventures than join other firms, with entrepreneurship having a larger adverse effect on source firm performance compared to moving to established firms.
original_filename: Campbell, B. A., Ganco, M., Franco, A. M., & Agarwal, R. (2012). Who leaves, where to, and why worry Employee mobility, entrepreneurship, and effects on source firm performance.pdf

title: A Scientific Approach to Entrepreneurial Decision Making
keywords: entrepreneurship, decisionmaking, scientificmethod, startup, randomizedcontroltrial
abstract: This paper explores the implications of a more scientific approach to entrepreneurial decision making by contrasting it with traditional search heuristics. The study uses a randomized control trial involving 116 Italian startups over about one year, finding that entrepreneurs who behave like scientists perform better and are less likely to drop out early in their ventures compared to those following intuition-based approaches.
original_filename: Camuffo, Cordova, Gambardella, & Spina MS 2020 A scientific approach to entrepreneurial decision making - Evidence from a randomized control trial.pdf

title: Customer Power, Strategic Investment, and the Failure of Leading Firms
keywords: customer power, strategic investment, technological change, resource allocation, industry leadership
abstract: Why might firms be regarded as astutely managed at one point yet subsequently lose their positions of industry leadership when faced with technological change? This paper presents a model grounded in a study of the world disk drive industry that charts how customer demands shape resource allocation in technological innovation. Established firms led the industry in developing technologies addressing existing customers' needs but failed to develop simpler technologies for emerging markets, as these were not seen as immediately profitable.
original_filename: Chistensen, Bower, 1996 Customer power, strategic investment, and the failure of leading firms.pdf

title: What Is a Patent Worth? Evidence From the U.S. Patent “Lottery”
keywords: patents, startup, innovation, employment growth, sales growth
abstract: We provide evidence on the value of patents to startups by leveraging the quasi-random assignment of applications to examiners with different propensities to grant patents. Using unique data on all first-time applications filed at the U.S. Patent Office since 2001, we find that startups winning the patent “lottery” have, on average, 55% higher employment growth and 80% higher sales growth five years later. Winning a first patent boosts subsequent growth and innovation by facilitating access to funding from venture capitalists, banks, and public investors.
original_filename: Farre‐Mensa, J., Hegde, D., & Ljungqvist, A. (2020). What is a patent worth-Evidence from the US patent “lottery”.pdf

title: The Theory-Based View: Economic Actors as Theorists
keywords: strategy, cognition, perception, theory for the firm, governance
abstract: This paper outlines the theory-based view of strategy and markets, arguing that novel or "great" strategies come from theories. Entrepreneurs and managers originate theories and hypotheses about their activities, assets to buy, and value creation methods. A firm's strategy then represents a unique, firm-specific point of view—a set of beliefs and a theory—about problem-solving and the organization and governance of value creation.
original_filename: Felin & Zenger SS 2017 The theory-based view - Economic actors as theorists.pdf

title: Theory-Based Decisions: Foundations and Introduction
keywords: theory-based view, decision making, strategy, entrepreneurship, causal reasoning
abstract: Theories are foundational for decision making. We emphasize the need for decision makers to develop their own theories using the scientific method— theories, causal reasoning, and experimentation—to problem solve and generate new value. This paper introduces the theory-based view (TBV), focusing on forward-looking reasoning and decision-making under uncertainty, and discusses its implications for key theories in strategy and economics.
original_filename: Felin, Gambardella, & Zenger SS 2024 Theory-based decisions - Foundations and introduction.pdf

title: A Scientific Method for Startups
keywords: entrepreneurship theory, lean startup, theory-based view, scientific method, startups
abstract: Recent scholarship has sought to develop a "scientific method" for startups by contrasting two approaches: lean startup and the theory-based view. While both emphasize the scientific approach, they differ in their underlying theoretical mechanisms and practical prescriptions, such as the focus on bounded rationality versus generative rationality. The paper highlights these differences and discusses opportunities for partial reconciliation and empirical comparison between the two perspectives.
original_filename: Felin, Gambardella, Novelli, & Zenger JOM 2024 A scientific method for startups.pdf

title: The Financing of Innovation
keywords: r&d, innovation, financing, liquidity constraints, venture capital
abstract: Evidence on the “funding gap” for innovation is surveyed. The focus is on financial market reasons for underinvestment in innovation that persist even in the absence of externality-induced underinvestment. The conclusions are that small and new innovative firms experience high costs of capital, while there are limits to venture capital as a solution to the funding gap.
original_filename: Hall, B. H. (2005). The financing of innovation. The Handbook of Technology and Innovation Management, 409-430..pdf

title: Structural Inertia and Organizational Change
keywords: organizational change, structural inertia, population ecology, selection processes, adaptation
abstract: Theory and research on organization-environment relations from a population ecology perspective have been based on the assumption that inertial pressures on structure are strong. This paper attempts to clarify the meaning of structural inertia and derive propositions about it from an explicit evolutionary model, treating high levels of structural inertia as a consequence of a selection process rather than a precondition for it. It also considers how the strength of inertial forces varies with age, size, and complexity.
original_filename: Hannan, Freeman, 1984, Structural Inertia and Organizational Change.pdf

title: Core Capabilities and Core Rigidities: a Paradox in Managing New Product Development
keywords: core capabilities, innovation, new product development, project management, organizational change
abstract: This paper examines the nature of core capabilities focusing on their interaction with new product development projects. It introduces two new concepts: core capabilities are deeply rooted in values, and they have a downside that hinders innovation, known as core rigidities. The study uses twenty case studies to illustrate how managers must navigate this paradox to leverage core capabilities while avoiding their limitations.
original_filename: Leonard‐Barton,1992 - Core capabilities and core rigidities  A paradox in managing new product development.pdf

title: Mobility, Skills, and the Michigan Non-Compete Experiment
keywords: mobility, non-compete agreements, employee mobility, skills, natural experiment
abstract: This paper explores a legal constraint on employee mobility—employeenon-competeagreements—by exploiting Michigan’s apparently inadvertent 1985 reversal of its non-compete enforcement policy as a natural experiment. Using a differences-in-differences approach, it finds that the enforcement of non-competes indeed attenuates mobility, more so for inventors with firm-specific skills and those specializing in narrow technical fields.
original_filename: Marx, M., Strumsky, D., & Fleming, L. (2009). Mobility, skills, and the Michigan non-compete experiment..pdf

title: Firm Boundaries Matter: Evidence From Conglomerates and R&D Activity
keywords: conglomerates, theory of firm, innovation, r&d, mergers
abstract: This paper examines the impact of the conglomerate form on the scale and novelty of corporate Research and Development (R&D) activity. I exploit a quasi-experiment involving failed mergers to generate exogenous variation in acquisition outcomes of target firms. Difference-in-differences estimation reveals that, relative to failed targets, firms acquired in diversifying mergers produce both fewer innovations and less-novel innovations.
original_filename: Seru, A. (2014). Firm boundaries matter- Evidence from conglomerates and R&D activity..pdf

title: Prior Knowledge and the Discovery of Entrepreneurial Opportunities
keywords: entrepreneurship, technological innovation, opportunity discovery, prior knowledge, cognitive feats
abstract: Technological innovations are usually thought to create business opportunities that are unequivocal and readily apparent to any knowledgeable observer. However, this article argues that opportunity discovery is a function of the distribution of information in society, drawing on Austrian economics. In-depth case studies demonstrate that entrepreneurs discover opportunities related to the information they already possess, suggesting that prior knowledge plays a crucial role in identifying entrepreneurial opportunities.
original_filename: Shane, S. (2000). Prior knowledge and the discovery of entrepreneurial opportunities.pdf

title: Screening Spinouts? How Noncompete Enforceability Affects the Creation, Growth, and Survival of New Firms
keywords: spinouts, start-ups, firmperformance, marketentry, noncompeteagreements
abstract: This paper examines how the enforceability of noncompete covenants affects the creation, growth, and survival of spinouts and other new entrants. The impact of noncompeteneenforceability on new firms is ambiguous since noncompetes reduce knowledge leakage but impose hiring costs. However, we posit that enforceability screens formation of within-industry spinouts (WSOs) relative to non-WSOs by dissuading founders with lower human capital.
original_filename: Starr, E., Balasubramanian, N., & Sakakibara, M. (2018). Screening spinouts-How noncompete enforceability affects the creation, growth, and survival of new firms..pdf

title: Entrepreneurs as Scientists: a Pragmatist Alternative to the Creation-Discovery Debate
keywords: entrepreneurs, pragmatism, creation-discovery, scientists, problem-solving
abstract: The paper challenges the traditional creation-discovery debate by advocating for an entrepreneur-as-scientist analogy from a pragmatist perspective. It argues that entrepreneurs act to create value, solving problems through scientific-like processes, and are not merely discoverers of pre-existing knowledge but creators of new solutions. This approach emphasizes that all humans, including entrepreneurs, engineers, and designers, behave as scientists in their problem-solving endeavors.
original_filename: Zellweger & Zenger AMR 2022 Entrepreneurs as scientists - A pragmatist alternative to the creation-discovery debate.pdf

title: Entrepreneurs as Scientists: a Pragmatist Approach to Producing Value Out of Uncertainty
keywords: pragmatism, entrepreneurship, uncertainty, value creation, scientific approach
abstract: Building on pragmatism, the paper advances an entrepreneur-as-scientist perspective, depicting entrepreneurs engaging in causally inferential actions by forming beliefs, testing them, and responding to feedback. However, this process comes with doubts about product-market fit, feedback validity, and over- or under-fitting responses. The authors discuss the rationality of heuristics deployed by entrepreneurs to overcome these doubts, contributing to the microfoundations of entrepreneurial action and strategy.
original_filename: Zellweger & Zenger AMR 2023 Entrepreneurs as scientists - A pragmatist approach to producing value out of uncertainty.pdf
